displayed_text: Patient: I’ve taken medicine. Doctor: Yes. Patient: I’m like eh. Doctor: So, really what I’m hearing here is that you’ll let me give you the blood. Healthcare Professional: Well uh, let’s see when Patient: Yeah, I can call in. I can call in. Doctor: Nobody leaves. Healthcare Professional: Let’s try it. Doctor: And then we’ll see about Dr. S_____. Nobody leaves. Nobody leaves. Patient: She said nobody leaves so I’m gonna sit here. Doctor: Nobody leave.

Patient: Right. I know. Yeah. That is. That is. Doctor: Unless it’s for a healer. You know? Patient: Yeah. (Laughter) Doctor: That is no good. Patient: Yeah. Remember when I was telling you about that, uh, um, HIV drug that they were doing some sort of testing on that was very good for, what was that, brain tumors? (Sound Door closes) Doctor: Yeah. So, I think they’re calling this the same thing. Vitamin B-seventeen is the laetrile? Patient: Yes. It is. It’s the same thing. Doctor: Yes. So I would say, uh, I think that’s not going to work. That would be my- Patient: Yeah. They don’t, they don’t, they don’t- Doctor: From what I know. From what I know about it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, so this is what the compound is. It’s called, amygdalin. And this is, it has cyanide. There it is, cyanide.

Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: Okay, so we’ll do that. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: And uh I want to see you in three months. Patient: Um hmm. How’s the blood. Doctor: Oh PSA. That’s the most important. Undetectable no evidence of any cancer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I mean really undetectable and we have to because a part of yours went into the seminal vesicle- Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: -we had to be very careful about following up on it because there’s a slight risk that it may reoccur, so we’ll follow it and follow it very carefully. Patient: I’ve been trying eat right, I’ve been trying to eat stuff, you know I’ve been trying to do my own you know like doing research and stuff that’s good for me. Doctor: Good. That’s good.

Patient: No, I don’t think so. Doctor: Well then next time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh the, I don’t know if they come back yet. I saw that… Patient: And I had a bone density done . And I sent that to her, I don’t know if you saw that? Doctor: Uh and G___ is what kind of doctor? Patient: Uh he’s my oncologist Patient: I’m presuming no. where I uh had the scans done Doctor: I’ll ask about it. My sense is don’t order a lot of those tests because Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: If you not having any bone or physical symptoms If it meets the threshold, they can give you a pill Patient: Yeah, yeah, at the same time, so

Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: I mean, again, if he takes them, he may eat less, but – um. Family Member: Are they just loaded with caffeine or something or? Doctor: Some of them are. Family Member: Oh. Okay. Doctor: So, when we saw you or you had came on April seventeenth, your white count was normal. You are anemic. I don’t think it’s really the iron. It may be your cancer and your treatment. It’s twenty-nine. Normal would be forty-one. Uh, and your platelets are okay. So, the only thing that we see is the low, uh, blood count, blood cells. Um. Your liver looks good. (Pause) Patient: I was on chemo ‘til February? Maybe that’s why the blood count’s down. I don’t know. (Pause) Family Member: Is that a (Pause35sec) Doctor: And your CAT scan (Pause15sec) Patient: Right. Doctor: They don’t really saw anything in your organs, your liver, all that looks good. Patient: Ah, okay. Doctor: And your bone scan (Pause6sec)

Patient: So, that’s good news that we can travel. I like being able to see the grandkids you know. Doctor: Yeah, yeah, and they’ll tell you exactly when and how long, you know, the kids, exposure, all of that he will explain. But we will start with giving you a side effects sheet and then I’ll have J____ come in and just tell J____, our nurse, Patient: Yeah, right. Doctor: about what to expect and how she’s going to do the prior authorization and then well we’ll kick you to the curb. Okay? Patient: Okay. Sounds good. Doctor: We’ll get out next one for I think it’s two months from now maybe for the shot. Family Member: Yeah. It will be the time for the Lupron. Doctor: Yes. We’ll see you guys back next time. Family Member: Congrats on your award. I see that J____ posted that. Doctor: Thank you. Patient: Thank you so much. Doctor: Alright, we’ll see you. Patient: Okay.

Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: You know if this is one of five lymph nodes, and you know the other four are invisible, then you drop by twenty percent. Family Member: If it drops by twenty percent, then we’ll know okay somewhere else - Doctor: cancer; we’ll look at the majority of the cancer where eighty percent went somewhere else. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: In the meantime you’ve bought a few months, maybe a year, of not starting hormone therapy. Patient: And it’s more of a proactive approach, you know like I had my prostate removed in two thousand and seven. There was no activity until two, well for ten years. Family Member: Right. Doctor: Uh hum, right. Patient: And then all of a sudden this stuff just popped up Doctor: Yeah. Patient: as opposed to two thousand and seven if there was a thing of saying well just to make sure we cleaned up everything, let’s do like a, give us, put together some chemo and do that.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.3 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::3 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: But sometimes it's vacation and special events and life. Patient: . Right now. Family Member: Okay, what if he goes on chemo- Doctor: Uh huh. Family Member: How is his reaction or side effects kind of differ from the way they are right now. Doctor: Well, that's, you know, for Xtandi, it's the potential tiredness, a little balance issues, none of which has plagued you, but chemo is more chemo usual chemo type of things, like hair thinning or hair loss. Family Member: We don’t worry about that. Doctor: You can get neuropathy, you know, over time, which is numbness and tingling. Patient: I can’t get more than I got. Doctor: Well, I'm hoping it's not that bad, you're stable, but you know, if it gets much worse you're not even eligible for the trial. The other parts are, you know, we watch the liver function, we check by blood test. Some people get a weird taste in their mouth, not necessarily metallic, but just doesn't taste right. Family Member: In other words, when he eats it’s not going to be as wonderful.

Patient: Oh. Doctor: I just had a meeting with him last week. Patient: Oh tell him I said hello next time you see him. Doctor: Yep. I was uh, I was talking to him. I said you got any idea? He goes, yeah, no, just do the chemo too. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Anyways. So I picked his brain. Patient: I mean, not, and please no, no offense. Doctor: No. No. Patient: Oh, yeah. I mean he I consider him part of my team. Doctor: Absolutely. Me too. Patient: You know? Doctor: Me too. Me So.

Patient: So, I don’t need this, right? Doctor: No. Show them this paperwork, but show them that, I was gonna say, show them that so that you make sure they cancel and give you a new one. Okay. But anyway, that’s fine. Patient: I’ll, I’ll Doctor: Show them this paperwork, and then they’ll give you all of those appointments. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Let me go work on your scripts, and I’ll be back. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I ain’t gotta take no shots, no hip shots, or Doctor: You are due for your Lupron. So, Patient: Which one is that? Doctor: The hormone. The Lupron shot.

Patient: So I think I'll stay the course and then we'll see what happens after that. Because I'm pretty good watching. If anything is swelling or if I’m having any pain. I'll be a little more vigilant now to go to the doctor whereas before I'm like. Doctor: Hopefully it doesn’t happen while you’re on the medicine. Patient: Right, no, I'm saying if I got off of it, I'd be a little more vigilant about the idea that if I have swelling, I should go to the doctor because it might not just be me being a macho jock, but I have a problem. Doctor: And so what I hear you say- is that you just got a prescription and how long is that going to be for? Patient: I think that's for three more months. Doctor: So that would be your plan to sort of go and then stop for six months. Healthcare Professional: Okay Patient: Yeah. That works for me. Doctor: Yeah. Blood work, Aximun scan. You're not on MyChart? Patient: I tried to get on MyChart, but the little number that he sent me, died or whatever. Doctor: Yeah, but I can we can print out a new one for you today. Patient: Okay good. Doctor: And then if you can just MyChart message me your email-

Patient: Right, okay. Doctor: So again, since you’re not eligible for that at this point in time - Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: A minimum PSA for that trial has to be above one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: One point zero. But just to prepare for the future – Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: I wanted to have that conversation with you. Patient: Uh hum. Sure. And this is the PSA level; you’re also saying we need to see something on the CT scan, right? Doctor: Correct. So for this particular trial, if the cancer is invisible, which will become non-metastatic. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: You would not be eligible. So it just has to do with; this trial is designed for a specific subset of patients so that cancer has to be both metastatic and hormone-resistant.

Patient: So then I’m eating, uh- Family Member: My diet. Doctor: You’re just eating protein. Patient: Seven days a week eating eggs. Doctor: Well, there’s other foods other than eggs. But carbs for you are like, forget it. Forget it. They’re disastrous. Family Member: Cancer feeds on it. Family Member: Right? Am I wrong there? Doctor: Well, it isn’t. You know what it is? It creates an unhealthy environment for you. And for all the other stuff I may potentially have to do for you, to you, however we want to say that, I need you functioning and that diabetes can’t be in my way. Gosh darn it. Doctor: Yeah. Plus unregulated, and I mean this up and down, your body just doesn’t like it. So the steady state might be alright at a hemoglobin A one C of seven two but your every day, what you get is tired. You crash. You go back up. You’re good. You crash. You’re tired. You come back up. That’s not, boom, okay. Patient: So then like I again explained to Dr. W___ about my, about my fatigue. Doctor: Um hum. Yes. Patient: Is my lack of uninterrupted sleep. I just don’t get it.

Family Member: …it’s dead quiet on Tuesday’s you know so that works out real well. But - Doctor: Perfect. Family Member: Obviously if it doesn’t work that way then we’ll just have to deal with it. Doctor: We’ll work around your schedule for that. Once we plan what study, then absolutely. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: As far as possible, I prefer Tuesday’s too so I would try and keep you on that. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But uh we’ll see how it goes. Family Member: Alright. I know in the beginning it will be more - Doctor: Next week though I was going to say just so we have enough time to get the results back, we should plan for like Thursday or Friday so we give it enough time because you know my worry is if I have you come in next Tuesday I may not have the results back from today’s blood work. Patient: Yeah, right. Family Member: So back here next Thursday or Friday?

Patient: DOD? Doctor: Yeah, the DOD. Patient: Wow. Doctor: I know; a lot of people are surprised. And this was a grant where the DOD wanted to fund a project that would a small benefit or have a transformative benefit. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: In other words a pretty huge benefit. And they were also looking for things that were paradigm shifts. In other words that runs against the grain. And so one of my colleagues from H___ applied for this grant. His name is Dr. ___. He was the mastermind behind this approach. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: He was awarded a grant. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So because it was a transformative impact grant, we decided to call the trial the Transformer Trial. So this is a study where we’re testing this high-dose testosterone therapy. Patient: Sure. Doctor: Now there are a few caveats about the trial that you need to be aware of. If your PSA goes above one after we do those scans (we can talk about that in more detail) Patient: Yeah.
